node.title: Sam Huff, Fearsome Hall of Fame Linebacker, Dies at 87
node.alt: Sam Huff in 1962. His intimidating aura was sealed on Oct. 30, 1960, when Walter Cronkite narrated the CBS documentary “The Violent World of Sam Huff.”
node.description: Huff, who became the epitome of the rough-and-tough football star with the Giants, was remembered for his head-on duels with two of the game’s greatest fullbacks.
node.content: ["Sam Huff, the Giants\u2019 Hall of Fame middle linebacker who became the face of pro football, his feats celebrated in the national news media, when the N.F.L. began to vie with major league baseball as America\u2019s No. 1 sport, died on Saturday in Winchester, Va. He was 87.", "His death, in a hospital, was confirmed by his daughter, Catherine Huff Myers, who said Huff learned he had dementia in 2013.", "Playing for the Giants in their glory years of the late 1950s and early \u201960s, Huff came out of the West Virginia coal country to anchor a defense that gained the kind of renown that had previously been reserved for strong-armed quarterbacks and elusive runners.", "He played in six N.F.L. championship games in his eight seasons with the Giants. He was named to the all-league team three times and played in five Pro Bowls.", "Huff was remembered for his head-on duels with two of the game\u2019s greatest fullbacks \u2014 the Cleveland Browns\u2019 Jim Brown and the Green Bay Packers\u2019 Jim Taylor \u2014 but he also had 30 career interceptions. He was inducted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame in 1982.", "Yankee Stadium, the Giants\u2019 home at the time, reverberated to chants of \u201cDEE-fense\u201d and \u201cHuff, Huff, Huff\u201d in the late 1950s as one of the N.F.L.\u2019s oldest teams became a glamorous franchise, vying with the baseball Yankees for media acclaim in America\u2019s communications capital.", "Huff became the epitome of the rough-and-tough football star.", "On Nov. 30, 1959 \u2014 almost a year after the thrilling sudden-death N.F.L. title game between the Giants and Baltimore Colts had launched pro football\u2019s ascendancy \u2014 Time magazine placed a portrait of Huff on its cover. He was the focus of \u201cA Man\u2019s Game,\u201d an article in that issue about pro football.", "Huff\u2019s fearsome aura was sealed on Oct. 30, 1960, when Walter Cronkite narrated the CBS documentary \u201cThe Violent World of Sam Huff,\u201d part of the series \u201cThe Twentieth Century.\u201d", "A microphone and a transmitter had been placed on Huff\u2019s shoulder pads for an exhibition game against the Chicago Bears in Toronto the previous August.", "Viewers saw and heard Huff calling signals in the huddle, then threatening a Bears receiver he considered to be taking liberties with him. \u201cYou do that again, you\u2019ll get a broken nose,\u201d Huff warned. \u201cDon\u2019t hit me on the chin with your elbow. I\u2019m not going to warn you no more.\u201d", "Burton Benjamin, the documentary\u2019s producer, later recalled in an article for The New York Times that the \u201cviolent world\u201d reference \u201cquickly became a part of the football lexicon.\u201d", "As Frank Gifford, the Giants\u2019 Hall of Fame running back and receiver, put it in his memoir \u201cThe Whole Ten Yards,\u201d Huff became \u201ca household name.\u201d", "Robert Lee Huff \u2014 he could not recall how he came to be called Sam \u2014 was born on Oct. 4, 1934, in Morgantown, W.Va., the son of a coal miner. He grew up in a mining camp known as Number Nine, outside Farmington, W.Va.", "Huff was an All-American at West Virginia University, a 6-foot-1-inch, 230-pound guard and tackle on both offense and defense. The Giants selected him in the third round of the 1956 N.F.L. draft.", "As a rookie, Huff played in the Giants\u2019 47-7 victory over the Bears in the 1956 N.F.L. championship game, and he became a key figure in the 4-3 alignment \u2014 four down linemen and three linebackers \u2014 installed by the Giants\u2019 defensive coordinator, Tom Landry. Replacing the 5-2 scheme commonly used, it put Huff at the heart of the action.", "\u201cBefore, I always had my head down, looking right into the center\u2019s helmet,\u201d Huff recalled in his memoir \u201cTough Stuff\u201d (1988, with Leonard Shapiro). \u201cNow I was standing up and I could see everything, and I mean everything. I always had outstanding peripheral vision. It\u2019s one of the reasons I was so perfectly suited for the position.\u201d", "The Giants\u2019 outstanding defensive linemen \u2014 Roosevelt Grier and Dick Modzelewski at tackle, Andy Robustelli and Jim Katcavage at end \u2014 kept blockers away from Huff, helping him to stop running plays. And he ranged back or moved toward the sidelines to break up passes, complementing the superb defensive backs Emlen Tunnell, Jim Patton and Dick Nolan.", "Huff \u201calmost single-handedly influenced the first chants of \u2018Defense, Defense\u2019 in Yankee Stadium,\u201d John K. Mara, the Giants\u2019 president and chief executive, said in a statement on Saturday.", "Following their championship season of 1956, the Giants won five division titles between 1958 and 1963, but they lost in the championship game each time.", "The Giants decided to reshape a veteran team following the 1963 season, when they won a third consecutive division title. They traded Huff to Washington for Dick James, a smallish running back, and Andy Stynchula, a defensive end.", "Huff was shocked and angered, and the two players acquired by the Giants did little for them. As the Giants\u2019 aging stars departed, the team descended into mediocrity. Huff gained retribution with Washington\u2019s 72-41 victory over the Giants in November 1966, which he once called \u201cthe one game I wanted the most.\u201d", "He played for Washington from 1964 to 1967, then retired, but he came back for a final season as a player and linebacker coach when Vince Lombardi was named Washington\u2019s head coach in 1969.", "Huff was later a longtime radio broadcaster for Washington games and a marketing executive for the Marriott hotel and resort chain. He also bred thoroughbred horses.", "Besides his daughter, Catherine, he is survived by his partner, Carol Holden; a son, Joseph; his former wife, Mary Helen Fletcher Huff; three grandchildren; and a great-grandchild, the family said. Another son, Robert Jr., died in 2018. Huff\u2019s marriage ended in divorce in the late 1980s.", "For anyone unfamiliar with \u201cThe Violent World of Sam Huff,\u201d the man in the middle of the Giants\u2019 awesome defense underlined his credo in a 2002 interview for the Pro Football Hall of Fame.", "\u201cI never let up on anybody,\u201d Huff said. \u201cI don\u2019t think I ever quit on a play. If you had the football, I was going to hit you, and when I hit you, I tried to hit you hard enough to hurt you. That\u2019s the way the game should be played.\u201d"]
